elements.content: The reaction of an equimolar mixture of uranyl and lanthanide nitrates with all- cis 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboxylic acid (H6L) under hydrothermal conditions gives the isomorphous complexes [UO2Ln(HL)(H2O)7]·H2O (Ln = Pr, Eu, Tb, Er), which are rare examples of uranyl−lanthanide heterometallic species. The three carboxylate groups in equatorial positions on the cyclohexane ring are bound to uranyl ions, thus generating a (63) hexagonal two-dimensional network. One of the carboxylate groups in an axial position chelates the [Ln(H2O)7]3+ group, resulting in the sheets being decorated by lanthanide ions on both sides.
elements.clean_text: The reaction of an equimolar mixture of uranyl and lanthanide nitrates with all- cis 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboxylic acid (H6L) under hydrothermal conditions gives the isomorphous complexes [UO2Ln(HL)(H2O)7]⋅H2O (Ln = Pr, Eu, Tb, Er), which are rare examples of uranyl-lanthanide heterometallic species. The three carboxylate groups in equatorial positions on the cyclohexane ring are bound to uranyl ions, thus generating a (63) hexagonal two-dimensional network. One of the carboxylate groups in an axial position chelates the [Ln(H2O)7]3+ group, resulting in the sheets being decorated by lanthanide ions on both sides.

elements.content: The two-dimensional hexagonal network formed by uranyl ions with the 5-fold deprotonated hexacarboxylic acid displays lanthanide heptahydrate appendages on both sides, thus giving a novel structural type in the very limited family of uranyl−lanthanide heterometallic complexes.
elements.clean_text: The two-dimensional hexagonal network formed by uranyl ions with the 5-fold deprotonated hexacarboxylic acid displays lanthanide heptahydrate appendages on both sides, thus giving a novel structural type in the very limited family of uranyl-lanthanide heterometallic complexes.

elements.content: The first examples of crystallographically characterized heterometallic coordination complexes uniting uranyl and lanthanide ions were reported only recently. One of them is a molecular species involving a cucurbit[6]uril ligand holding one uranyl ion and one lanthanide (Sm, Eu, Gd, Lu) ion at one of its portals, while the other is a family of two- and three-dimensional assemblies with DOTA (1,4,7,10-tetraazacyclododecane-N,N′,N′′,N′′′-tetraacetate) and oxalato ligands, in which the lanthanide ion (Sm, Eu, Gd) occupies the inner N4O4 site of the macrocycle and the uranyl ions are located outside and ensure the building of the framework. Some examples of mixed uranyl−lanthanide mineral compounds are also known. Up to now, apart from the case of DOTA, no such complex could be obtained with polycarboxylic acids, which are much used for the synthesis of uranyl−organic polymers and frameworks. Numerous attempts with various acids generally yielded the uranyl-only complex instead of the mixed species. However, the use of all- cis 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboxylic acid (denoted H6L hereafter) permitted the isolation of a family of heterometallic complexes of unusual structure which are described herein.
elements.clean_text: The first examples of crystallographically characterized heterometallic coordination complexes uniting uranyl and lanthanide ions were reported only recently. One of them is a molecular species involving a cucurbit[6]uril ligand holding one uranyl ion and one lanthanide (Sm, Eu, Gd, Lu) ion at one of its portals, while the other is a family of two- and three-dimensional assemblies with DOTA (1,4,7,10-tetraazacyclododecane-N,N',N'',N'''-tetraacetate) and oxalato ligands, in which the lanthanide ion (Sm, Eu, Gd) occupies the inner N4O4 site of the macrocycle and the uranyl ions are located outside and ensure the building of the framework. Some examples of mixed uranyl-lanthanide mineral compounds are also known. Up to now, apart from the case of DOTA, no such complex could be obtained with polycarboxylic acids, which are much used for the synthesis of uranyl-organic polymers and frameworks. Numerous attempts with various acids generally yielded the uranyl-only complex instead of the mixed species. However, the use of all- cis 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboxylic acid (denoted H6L hereafter) permitted the isolation of a family of heterometallic complexes of unusual structure which are described herein.

elements.content: Reaction of equimolar amounts of uranyl and lanthanide nitrates with H6L under hydrothermal conditions gave the complexes [UO2Ln(HL)(H2O)7]·H2O, with Ln = Pr (1), Eu (2), Tb (3), and Er (4), which were crystallographically characterized. These complexes are isomorphous, with the asymmetric unit containing one uranyl ion and one lanthanide ion, both located on mirror planes, half a 5-fold deprotonated ligand, four coordinated water molecules (one of them on the mirror plane), and a free water molecule, also on the mirror plane (Figure ). The uranyl ion is bound to three chelating carboxylate groups pertaining to three HL5− molecules, with an unexceptional U−O bond length averaged over all compounds of 2.49(3) Å. The uranium coordination polyhedron is thus hexagonal bipyramidal, with the oxo atoms in axial positions, as usual with small-bite ligands.
elements.clean_text: Reaction of equimolar amounts of uranyl and lanthanide nitrates with H6L under hydrothermal conditions gave the complexes [UO2Ln(HL)(H2O)7]⋅H2O, with Ln = Pr (1), Eu (2), Tb (3), and Er (4), which were crystallographically characterized. These complexes are isomorphous, with the asymmetric unit containing one uranyl ion and one lanthanide ion, both located on mirror planes, half a 5-fold deprotonated ligand, four coordinated water molecules (one of them on the mirror plane), and a free water molecule, also on the mirror plane (Figure ). The uranyl ion is bound to three chelating carboxylate groups pertaining to three HL5- molecules, with an unexceptional U-O bond length averaged over all compounds of 2.49(3) Å. The uranium coordination polyhedron is thus hexagonal bipyramidal, with the oxo atoms in axial positions, as usual with small-bite ligands.

elements.content: View of complex 1. Displacement ellipsoids are drawn at the 50% probability level. Hydrogen bonds are shown as dashed lines. The solvent water molecule is omitted. Symmetry codes: ′ = x, 3/2 − y, z; ′′ = 1/2 − x, y − 1/2, z − 1/2; ′′′ = 1/2 − x, 2 − y, z − 1/2; # = x, 5/2 − y, z; $ = x, y + 1, z; ∧ = 1/2 − x, 2 − y, z + 1/2. Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (deg): U−O1, 1.763(7); U−O2, 1.764(8); U−O3, 2.457(5); U−O4, 2.513(5); U−O9′′, 2.520(5); Pr−O5, 2.510(6); Pr−O6, 2.523(7); Pr−O10, 2.426(7); Pr−O11, 2.482(5); Pr−O12, 2.526(5); Pr−O13, 2.555(5); O1−U−O2, 178.6(3); O3−U−O4, 52.14(15); O4−U−O4′, 65.1(2); O3′−U−O9′′, 69.89(16); O9′′−U−O9′′′, 51.1(2); O5−Pr−O6, 51.6(2).

Symmetry codes: ' = x, 3/2 - y, z; '' = 1/2 - x, y - 1/2, z - 1/2; ''' = 1/2 - x, 2 - y, z - 1/2; # = x, 5/2 - y, z; $ = x, y + 1, z; ∧ = 1/2 - x, 2 - y, z + 1/2. Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (deg): U-O1, 1.763(7); U-O2, 1.764(8); U-O3, 2.457(5); U-O4, 2.513(5); U-O9'', 2.520(5); Pr-O5, 2.510(6); Pr-O6, 2.523(7); Pr-O10, 2.426(7); Pr-O11, 2.482(5); Pr-O12, 2.526(5); Pr-O13, 2.555(5); O1-U-O2, 178.6(3); O3-U-O4, 52.14(15); O4-U-O4', 65.1(2); O3'-U-O9'', 69.89(16); O9''-U-O9''', 51.1(2); O5-Pr-O6, 51.6(2).

elements.content: The lanthanide ion is bound to one slightly asymmetric chelating carboxylate group, with average Ln−O bond lengths of 2.517(7), 2.476(12), 2.45(3), and 2.42(3) Å for 1−4, respectively, with the increasing population standard deviation indicating an increasing asymmetry when the ion radius decreases. Seven water molecules complete the coordination sphere, with average Ln−O(water) bond lengths of 2.51(4), 2.45(4), 2.43(4), and 2.39(4) Å for 1−4, respectively. All these values lie within the range found for the similar groups reported in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, version 5.31). The lanthanide ion coordination polyhedron is a distorted capped square antiprism with one square face defined by atoms O5, O10, O11, O11#, the other by O12, O13, O12#, O13# (dihedral angle ca. 1−2°), and O6 in the capping position.
elements.clean_text: The lanthanide ion is bound to one slightly asymmetric chelating carboxylate group, with average Ln-O bond lengths of 2.517(7), 2.476(12), 2.45(3), and 2.42(3) Å for 1-4, respectively, with the increasing population standard deviation indicating an increasing asymmetry when the ion radius decreases. Seven water molecules complete the coordination sphere, with average Ln-O(water) bond lengths of 2.51(4), 2.45(4), 2.43(4), and 2.39(4) Å for 1-4, respectively. All these values lie within the range found for the similar groups reported in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, version 5.31). The lanthanide ion coordination polyhedron is a distorted capped square antiprism with one square face defined by atoms O5, O10, O11, O11#, the other by O12, O13, O12#, O13# (dihedral angle ca. 1-2°), and O6 in the capping position.

elements.content: The HL5− ligand, in the chair conformation, admits a plane of symmetry containing atoms C2, C4 and the carboxylate group C6, O5, O6 and bisecting the carboxylate group C8, O9, O9#. The carboxylic/ate groups are alternately in axial and equatorial positions on the cyclohexane ring, with this configuration being reported to be less stable than that of the all-trans form with all groups equatorial in the case of H6L. The equatorial carboxylate groups are bound to three uranyl ions and that located in the symmetry plane, in an axial position, to the lanthanide ion. The two remaining axial groups are hydrogen bonded to one another by the disordered hydrogen atom. The ligand is thus a nearly planar, trigonal node for uranyl, through its equatorial sites, and this results in the formation of a two-dimensional, slightly undulated hexagonal assembly parallel to the bc plane, with the total point symbol (63). The lanthanide ions do not contribute to the building of the polymer (as in most complexes with DOTA2), since they are bound to only one HL5− molecule. They are located on either side of the layers and can be viewed as decorating units (Figure ). The anionic uranyl−organic planes are separated from one another by layers of [Ln(H2O)7]3+ pendent groups, with the water ligands being involved in intra- as well as interlayer hydrogen bonds. The arrangement is very tight, with no free space present, as indicated by the packing index of ca. 0.82 (estimated with PLATON).
elements.clean_text: The HL5- ligand, in the chair conformation, admits a plane of symmetry containing atoms C2, C4 and the carboxylate group C6, O5, O6 and bisecting the carboxylate group C8, O9, O9#. The carboxylic/ate groups are alternately in axial and equatorial positions on the cyclohexane ring, with this configuration being reported to be less stable than that of the all-trans form with all groups equatorial in the case of H6L. The equatorial carboxylate groups are bound to three uranyl ions and that located in the symmetry plane, in an axial position, to the lanthanide ion. The two remaining axial groups are hydrogen bonded to one another by the disordered hydrogen atom. The ligand is thus a nearly planar, trigonal node for uranyl, through its equatorial sites, and this results in the formation of a two-dimensional, slightly undulated hexagonal assembly parallel to the bc plane, with the total point symbol (63). The lanthanide ions do not contribute to the building of the polymer (as in most complexes with DOTA2), since they are bound to only one HL5- molecule. They are located on either side of the layers and can be viewed as decorating units (Figure ). The anionic uranyl-organic planes are separated from one another by layers of [Ln(H2O)7]3+ pendent groups, with the water ligands being involved in intra- as well as interlayer hydrogen bonds. The arrangement is very tight, with no free space present, as indicated by the packing index of ca. 0.82 (estimated with PLATON).

elements.content: The present compounds are interesting from several viewpoints. They are rare examples of uranyl complexes with cyclohexane carboxylate derivatives, since only three other cases are reported in the CSD, one with a derivative of Kemp’s triacid and the others with 1,3-cyclohexanedicarboxylate. In contrast, several lanthanide complexes with 1,3- and 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylates and 1,3,5-cyclohexanetricarboxylate are present in the CSD. H6L has not been widely used as a ligand up to now, and only d transition metal complexes have been reported, but lanthanide complexes were obtained in the course of the present study and will be reported in a forthcoming paper. Compounds 1−4 are thus the first f element complexes involving this hexacarboxylic/ate ligand, which appears perfectly suited to build hexagonal networks with the uranyl ion, with both cation and anion being trigonal nodes. They are also among the exceedingly rare uranyl−lanthanide heterometallic complexes, and in this context, they provide a novel mode of association of these cations. In the two other examples known of such complexes, the 4f and 5f ions occupy either identical or extremely different coordination sites. In the present compounds, both cations are chelated by carboxylate groups, but these groups are inequivalent by being in either equatorial or axial positions. Considering the uranyl propensity to form quasi-planar networks through bonding in its equatorial plane, the former are well adapted to form a regular extended architecture. Among the three axial groups pointing toward the same side of the cyclohexane ring, one is thus free to pick a hydrated lanthanide ion as a terminal appendage (coordination of the others being likely prevented, since it would result in too much crowding).

In contrast, several lanthanide complexes with 1,3- and 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylates and 1,3,5-cyclohexanetricarboxylate are present in the CSD. H6L has not been widely used as a ligand up to now, and only d transition metal complexes have been reported, but lanthanide complexes were obtained in the course of the present study and will be reported in a forthcoming paper. Compounds 1-4 are thus the first f element complexes involving this hexacarboxylic/ate ligand, which appears perfectly suited to build hexagonal networks with the uranyl ion, with both cation and anion being trigonal nodes. They are also among the exceedingly rare uranyl-lanthanide heterometallic complexes, and in this context, they provide a novel mode of association of these cations. In the two other examples known of such complexes, the 4f and 5f ions occupy either identical or extremely different coordination sites. In the present compounds, both cations are chelated by carboxylate groups, but these groups are inequivalent by being in either equatorial or axial positions. Considering the uranyl propensity to form quasi-planar networks through bonding in its equatorial plane, the former are well adapted to form a regular extended architecture. Among the three axial groups pointing toward the same side of the cyclohexane ring, one is thus free to pick a hydrated lanthanide ion as a terminal appendage (coordination of the others being likely prevented, since it would result in too much crowding).

elements.content: Top: View of the two-dimensional assembly in 1, showing one layer in the bc plane. Bottom: View of the packing down the b axis. The uranyl coordination polyhedra are in yellow, and those of praseodymium are in blue. Hydrogen atoms and solvent molecules are omitted.
elements.clean_text: 2  Top: View of the two-dimensional assembly in 1, showing one layer in the bc plane. Bottom: View of the packing down the b axis. The uranyl coordination polyhedra are in yellow, and those of praseodymium are in blue. Hydrogen atoms and solvent molecules are omitted.

elements.content: Alkali- or alkaline earth-decorated metal−organic frameworks have been investigated for their potential as H2-storage materials. Numerous compounds which can be seen as decorated inorganic or metal−organic frameworks can also be found in d block metal chemistry. Concerning uranium-containing polymers, some examples have been described, such as [UF8]∞ chains decorated with pendent [UO2F5]3− groups, uranyl phosphate or phosphonate one- or two-dimensional polymers with [Ag(2,2′-bipy)]+ or [Cu(H2O) x ]2+ (x = 2, 3) units, respectively, or a uranyl−organic two-dimensional assembly, also with [Ag(2,2′-bipy)]+ groups. However, compounds 1−4 are unique examples of such an arrangement involving lanthanide ions, which demonstrate that uranyl−lanthanide heterometallic complexes of unprecedented architecture can be obtained with ligands comprising only carboxylate donors.
elements.clean_text: Alkali- or alkaline earth-decorated metal-organic frameworks have been investigated for their potential as H2-storage materials. Numerous compounds which can be seen as decorated inorganic or metal-organic frameworks can also be found in d block metal chemistry. Concerning uranium-containing polymers, some examples have been described, such as [UF8]∞ chains decorated with pendent [UO2F5]3- groups, uranyl phosphate or phosphonate one- or two-dimensional polymers with [Ag(2,2'-bipy)]+ or [Cu(H2O) x ]2+ (x = 2, 3) units, respectively, or a uranyl-organic two-dimensional assembly, also with [Ag(2,2'-bipy)]+ groups. However, compounds 1-4 are unique examples of such an arrangement involving lanthanide ions, which demonstrate that uranyl-lanthanide heterometallic complexes of unprecedented architecture can be obtained with ligands comprising only carboxylate donors.

elements.content: Tables of crystal data, atomic positions and displacement parameters, anisotropic displacement parameters, and bond lengths and bond angles in CIF format. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Tables of crystal data, atomic positions and displacement parameters, anisotropic displacement parameters, and bond lengths and bond angles in CIF format. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.content: Synthesis of 1−4. Uranyl nitrate hexahydrate (25 mg, 0.05 mmol), either praseodymium nitrate tetrahydrate (20 mg, 0.05 mmol), europium nitrate pentahydrate (22 mg, 0.05 mmol), terbium nitrate hexahydrate (23 mg, 0.05 mmol), or erbium nitrate pentahydrate (22 mg, 0.05 mmol), 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboxylic acid monohydrate (37 mg, 0.10 mmol), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure, yielding pale yellow, needle-shaped crystals of complexes 1−4, respectively, within one to ten days (11 mg, 24% yield based on the metal ions in the case of 2). Anal. Calcd for C12H23EuO22U (2): C, 15.85; H, 2.55. Found: C, 16.29; H, 2.68.
elements.clean_text:
References

Synthesis of 1-4. Uranyl nitrate hexahydrate (25 mg, 0.05 mmol), either praseodymium nitrate tetrahydrate (20 mg, 0.05 mmol), europium nitrate pentahydrate (22 mg, 0.05 mmol), terbium nitrate hexahydrate (23 mg, 0.05 mmol), or erbium nitrate pentahydrate (22 mg, 0.05 mmol), 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboxylic acid monohydrate (37 mg, 0.10 mmol), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure, yielding pale yellow, needle-shaped crystals of complexes 1-4, respectively, within one to ten days (11 mg, 24% yield based on the metal ions in the case of 2). Anal. Calcd for C12H23EuO22U (2): C, 15.85; H, 2.55. Found: C, 16.29; H, 2.68.

elements.content: Crystallographic data were collected at 150(2) K on a Nonius Kappa-CCD area-detector diffractometer and processed with HKL2000. Absorption effects were corrected with SCALEPACK. The structure of 2 was solved by direct methods and was used as a starting point for the other compounds. The structures were refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXTL. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen atoms were found on Fourier-difference maps (independently for each compound), except for the solvent water molecule in 1, 2, and 4. The proton bound to O8 was given an occupancy factor of 0.5 for charge balance and to account for its closeness to its image by symmetry. The carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were introduced at calculated positions. The drawings were done with SHELXTL and Balls & Sticks. Crystal data for 1: C12H23O22PrU, M = 898.24, orthorhombic, space group Pnma, a = 12.5966(6), b = 10.0059(5), c = 16.6085(10) Å, V = 2093.34(19) Å3, Z = 4. Refinement of 181 parameters on 2106 independent reflections out of 47861 measured reflections (R int = 0.031) led to R1 = 0.035, wR2 = 0.075, S = 1.044, Δρmin = −1.00, Δρmax = 3.74 e Å−3. Crystal data for 2: C12H23EuO22U, M = 909.29, orthorhombic, space group Pnma, a = 12.5112(2), b = 10.0160(2), c = 16.6003(3) Å, V = 2080.22(7) Å3, Z = 4. Refinement of 181 parameters on 2089 independent reflections out of 40164 measured reflections (R int = 0.015) led to R1 = 0.031, wR2 = 0.076, S = 1.167, Δρmin = −1.43, Δρmax = 0.85 e Å−3. Crystal data for 3: C12H23O22TbU, M = 916.25, orthorhombic, space group Pnma, a = 12.4231(2), b = 9.9984(2), c = 16.5817(4) Å, V = 2059.63(7) Å3, Z = 4. Refinement of 181 parameters on 2070 independent reflections out of 43627 measured reflections (R int = 0.020) led to R1 = 0.028, wR2 = 0.063, S = 1.121, Δρmin = −1.28, Δρmax = 0.91 e Å−3. Crystal data for 4: C12H23ErO22U, M = 924.59, orthorhombic, space group Pnma, a = 12.3630(3), b = 10.0071(2), c = 16.5727(5) Å, V = 2050.34(9) Å3, Z = 4. Refinement of 181 parameters on 2059 independent reflections out of 42433 measured reflections (R int = 0.033) led to R1 = 0.036, wR2 = 0.069, S = 1.072, Δρmin = −1.22, Δρmax = 0.96 e Å−3.

Refinement of 181 parameters on 2059 independent reflections out of 42433 measured reflections (R int = 0.033) led to R1 = 0.036, wR2 = 0.069, S = 1.072, Δρmin = -1.22, Δρmax = 0.96 e Å-3.

cln_elements.content: Crystallographic data were collected at 150(2) K on a Nonius Kappa-CCD area-detector diffractometer and processed with HKL2000. Absorption effects were corrected with SCALEPACK. The structure of 2 was solved by direct methods and was used as a starting point for the other compounds. The structures were refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXTL. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen atoms were found on Fourier-difference maps (independently for each compound), except for the solvent water molecule in 1, 2, and 4. The proton bound to O8 was given an occupancy factor of 0.5 for charge balance and to account for its closeness to its image by symmetry. The carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were introduced at calculated positions. The drawings were done with SHELXTL and Balls & Sticks. Crystal data for 1: C12H23O22PrU, M = 898.24, orthorhombic, space group Pnma, a = 12.5966(6), b = 10.0059(5), c = 16.6085(10) Å, V = 2093.34(19) Å3, Z = 4. Refinement of 181 parameters on 2106 independent reflections out of 47861 measured reflections (R int = 0.031) led to R1 = 0.035, wR2 = 0.075, S = 1.044, Δρmin = −1.00, Δρmax = 3.74 e Å−3. Crystal data for 2: C12H23EuO22U, M = 909.29, orthorhombic, space group Pnma, a = 12.5112(2), b = 10.0160(2), c = 16.6003(3) Å, V = 2080.22(7) Å3, Z = 4. Refinement of 181 parameters on 2089 independent reflections out of 40164 measured reflections (R int = 0.015) led to R1 = 0.031, wR2 = 0.076, S = 1.167, Δρmin = −1.43, Δρmax = 0.85 e Å−3. Crystal data for 3: C12H23O22TbU, M = 916.25, orthorhombic, space group Pnma, a = 12.4231(2), b = 9.9984(2), c = 16.5817(4) Å, V = 2059.63(7) Å3, Z = 4. Refinement of 181 parameters on 2070 independent reflections out of 43627 measured reflections (R int = 0.020) led to R1 = 0.028, wR2 = 0.063, S = 1.121, Δρmin = −1.28, Δρmax = 0.91 e Å−3. Crystal data for 4: C12H23ErO22U, M = 924.59, orthorhombic, space group Pnma, a = 12.3630(3), b = 10.0071(2), c = 16.5727(5) Å, V = 2050.34(9) Å3, Z = 4. Refinement of 181 parameters on 2059 independent reflections out of 42433 measured reflections (R int = 0.033) led to R1 = 0.036, wR2 = 0.069, S = 1.072, Δρmin = −1.22, Δρmax = 0.96 e Å−3.

cln_elements.content: View of complex 1. Displacement ellipsoids are drawn at the 50% probability level. Hydrogen bonds are shown as dashed lines. The solvent water molecule is omitted. Symmetry codes: ′ = x, 3/2 − y, z; ′′ = 1/2 − x, y − 1/2, z − 1/2; ′′′ = 1/2 − x, 2 − y, z − 1/2; # = x, 5/2 − y, z; $ = x, y + 1, z; ∧ = 1/2 − x, 2 − y, z + 1/2. Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (deg): U−O1, 1.763(7); U−O2, 1.764(8); U−O3, 2.457(5); U−O4, 2.513(5); U−O9′′, 2.520(5); Pr−O5, 2.510(6); Pr−O6, 2.523(7); Pr−O10, 2.426(7); Pr−O11, 2.482(5); Pr−O12, 2.526(5); Pr−O13, 2.555(5); O1−U−O2, 178.6(3); O3−U−O4, 52.14(15); O4−U−O4′, 65.1(2); O3′−U−O9′′, 69.89(16); O9′′−U−O9′′′, 51.1(2); O5−Pr−O6, 51.6(2).

cln_elements.content: Top: View of the two-dimensional assembly in 1, showing one layer in the bc plane. Bottom: View of the packing down the b axis. The uranyl coordination polyhedra are in yellow, and those of praseodymium are in blue. Hydrogen atoms and solvent molecules are omitted.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Top: View of the two-dimensional assembly in 1, showing one layer in the bc plane. Bottom: View of the packing down the b axis. The uranyl coordination polyhedra are in yellow, and those of praseodymium are in blue. Hydrogen atoms and solvent molecules are omitted.

metadata.title:
A Lanthanide Ion-Decorated Uranyl−Organic Two-Dimensional Assembly with all-cis
 1,2,3,4,5,6-Cyclohexanehexacarboxylic Acid
